instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not Turning On
threads.message:
Hello,

I receive a MacBook Pro that does not want to turn on. I found there was a shorted <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> (unsure if CPU is fried already). Replaced, fan spin and was ready to put together to test, but no longer getting a fan spin after unplugging and replugging charger. Checked <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> not present. Removed PWRGD resistors one by one and finally <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> which brought <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> back. Fan spins again, however there is 0 volts CPU vcore on all coils. I tried replacing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, no go. Measurements I think are pointing back to <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, but is there anything else I should check?

Any advice? Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not Turning On
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> is a redundant protection; you can leave it out.
However, be sure 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V35_S3</SIGNAL> are all present.

"I tried replacing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>"
Any reason to do that?

I bet for dead CPU, because of overvoltage cuased by <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>.
Just in case, compare diode mode to ground at L7310/20/30 with a good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not Turning On
threads.message:
Alright, I kept <TRANSISTOR>Q8105</TRANSISTOR> off. 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V35_S3</SIGNAL> all present.

I replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> again and CPU Vcore all 3 coils went between 1.2 to 1.6 volts, fan spin for a good 5-10 seconds and then went dead again. Replugging the power and it did the same thing. Did it a 3rd, 4th, 5th time, etc and now it's just dead 0 volts - no fan spin. Intermittent issue where if I keep it unplugged for longer then plugging it back in allows the fan to spin and a pulse on vcore. Perhaps <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is bad or this is consistent with a fried CPU. I don't have a good board to test it against.

I have more <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>'s coming in and will try replacing all 3 mosfets too since I replaced only 1 (is that a good idea?).

There are some PGOOD signals I want to check, but the board view I have is not exact making it pretty difficult to troubleshoot some parts of the board.
